questions.question_text: What command is used to download data from a Snowflake stage?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
GET
Downloads data files from one of the following Snowflake stages to a local directory/folder on a client machine:

Named internal stage.

Internal stage for a specified table.

Internal stage for the current user.

Typically, this command is executed after using the COPY INTO <location> command to unload data from a table into a Snowflake stage.

Selected Answer: C
Why GET and why not COPY. If the questions is about Unloading and Uploading the data, then its COPY. Again, they did not tell Data Files in the question. If its Data Files then GET is the answer. But they used the word DOWNLOAD. so let us assume the DATA meant here is DATA FILES. so its GET

Selected Answer: C
Verified

Selected Answer: C
for sure GET. its from documentation

Selected Answer: C
GET COMMAND

questions.question_text: By default, which role has privileges to create tables and views in an account?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Sequence-generated Columns
Do not expose the sequence-generated column as part of the view.

The correct answer is D.
Do not expose the sequence-generated column(s).

Snowflake recommendation:
1) Do not expose the sequence-generated column as part of the view.
2) Use randomized identifiers (e.g. generated by UUID_STRING) instead of sequence-generated values.
3) Programmatically obfuscate the identifiers.

https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/views-secure#sequence-generated-columns

Selected Answer: D
correct

comments.content: based on your link Answer is D. (Use randomized identifiers (e.g. generated by UUID_STRING) instead of sequence-generated values.)

discussion.content:
D
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/views-secure

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

questions.question_text: What does Snowflake recommend as a best practice for using secure views?

choices.C: Use secure views solely for query convenience.
choices.D: Do not expose the sequence-generated column(s).

questions.question_text: What is the Fail-safe period for a transient table in the Snowflake Enterprise edition and higher?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Temporary and Transient TablesÂ¶
To help manage the storage costs associated with Time Travel and Fail-safe, Snowflake provides two table types, temporary and transient, which do not incur the same fees as standard (i.e. permanent) tables:

Transient tables can have a Time Travel retention period of either 0 or 1 day.

Temporary tables can also have a Time Travel retention period of 0 or 1 day; however, this retention period ends as soon as the table is dropped or the session in which the table was created ends.

Transient and temporary tables have no Fail-safe period.

As a result, the maximum

Selected Answer: A
Zero is the answer

Selected Answer: A
Similar to permanent tables, transient tables contribute to the overall storage charges that Snowflake bills your account; however, because transient tables do not utilize Fail-safe, there are no Fail-safe costs (i.e. the costs associated with maintaining the data required for Fail-safe disaster recovery).

Selected Answer: A
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/tables-temp-transient
Transient tables are similar to permanent tables with the key difference that they do not have a Fail-safe period

Selected Answer: A
Failsafe is 0 for temporary and transient

Selected Answer: A
A is correct.

questions.question_text: How does a Snowflake user enable Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)?

choices.A: The user must enroll themselves through the web interface.
choices.C: The user must sign up with Duo Mobile for approval to use the service.
choices.D: The user must configure Snowflake to use Single Sign-On (SSO).
choices.B: The user must submit their encrypted private key to Snowflake.
